repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project in Malawi were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) With upfront agreement of core policy
            and regulatory reforms, sector institutional development can
            be successfully carried out, even in a weak country
            environment provided there is a long term support to
            implementation of second order reforms generated through
            project activities; 2) With newly established institutions,
            caution needs to be exercised in estimation of
            implementation capacity and there needs to be greater
            pro-activity on part of the Bank and the Borrower to adjust
            to the realities on the ground; 3) Effective government
            ownership and support from the development partners, can
            lead to initially weak institutions being challenged to
            deliver more than average results even under adverse
            macroeconomic environment; 4) Continuity of task team
            leadership and ensuring an adequate skill mix, contributes
            positively to the outcomes of a project; and 5) For
            successful monitoring and use of indicators, there needs to
            be a periodic review of indicators to reflect current
            country and Bank objectives. This is critical for projects
            such as this where there is a long period (10 years) between
            appraisal and project closing.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project (ROMARP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation
            Project (ROMARP) aims to bring about sustainable
            improvements in the quality of Malawi's road
            infrastructure by reducing transport costs and improving
            access. The project consists of four components. 1)
            Strengthening the road sector institutional framework will
            support institutional development and changes in various
            road sector agencies to accommodate the new sector policy
            framework. It will also support capacity building and skills
            development of road sector personnel for sustainable road
            sector management. 2) Development of the construction and
            consulting industries will support the establishment of the
            National Construction Industry Council as the principal
            stakeholder representative body for the development of the
            local industry and will support the development and
            implementation of action plans to address industry
            constraints. 3) Support to sustainable periodic maintenance
            will cover priority periodic maintenance requirements of the
            core network to assure road infrastructure quality. 4)
            Support to selective rehabilitation and upgrading will cover
            a limited amount of rehabilitation of the paved road network
            and a limited amount of earth to gravel or gravel to paved upgrading.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project - environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation
            Project aims over the period 1998-2002 to address the
            backlog of maintenance on main and rural roads and to put
            into place road sector institutional arrangements to improve
            the effectiveness of sector management and to ensure
            sustainable local financing for road maintenance. This
            preliminary study provides advice and guidance on the
            requirements for environmental impact assessment and
            mitigation in the road sector in Malawi. The report
            discusses the context in which the road sector now operates
            including the current legislative and administrative
            framework. It also discusses how the road sector can address
            the requirements and minimize the potential environment
            impact. The report also emphasizes the importance of
            community participation at all stages. The report also
            includes an environmental impact assessment guidelines, with
            detailed checklists and information relating specifically to
            the road sector. They would provide parties involved in the
            environmental impact assessment and mitigation with a simple
            effective and uniform method so that the whole process
            making is easier to undertake and manage.

docna.cdata!:
Malawi - Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation
            Project - environmental impact assessment
